Call me a purist - I'm not really, provided any changes improve upon an original formula, then I'm all for them - but Revolution Games/Charles Cecil should have simply remastered the original 'Shadow of the Templars', like how they did with 'The Smoking Mirror', instead of reimagining this classic game by editing out classic dialogue and applying pointless changes elsewhere, to what was already a perfect game.  Also, George Stobbart is the star of the show here, and the game should have still opened with him in that unforgettable clown scene at the caf√©. I remember playing this game for first time on a PlayStation demo disc (and subsequently fully on Windows 95 PC) back in around 1997, and that introduction was simply astounding and I'll never forget the feeling of shock and intrigue after seeing it. Yet, the creators saw fit to tamper with perfection and attempt to make Nico the equal of George, which she never was. Don't get me wrong, it was great that the character of Nico was reprised in the Broken Sword franchise's sequels (though sadly with different voice actresses), and that you get to play as her occasionally, as she is, after all, an integral character. But George Stobbart is why we really play the Broken Sword games, and changes shouldn't have been made for the what seems to be the simple aim of including additional puzzles at the expense of narrative and character placement/development.  This is still a great game, but I recommended playing the original game instead (even if it is without the polish of this 'director's cut' remaster) which comes packaged with this 'Director's Cut' on GOG (good old games) on the PC. It's just a shame that the creators didn't see these futile revisions for the missteps and regressions that they are, and just focused on revamping and updating the user interface and presentation like they did with the second game. A missed opportunity, but not a disaster.

This is fine for nostalgia purposes but what happened to the real broken sword? People are missing after certain events, dialogue has been missed out, the people aren't animated when talking, puzzles are made a lot easier and in some cases done for you or just plain replaced with shoddy mobile mini-games, and you can't die!! I know some people aren't fond of dying in point and click adventures but that's what made this one quite tricky. This game has been made too easy, too quickly with bugs all over the place. If this will be your first time playing this fantastic game then please, please get it on steam or gog first. You get the mobile version with it on those sites too.

Le pondr√≠a un 10 si pudiera.  Es un remake del juego original creado en 1996 cuando en aquel tiempo estaba para los PC's y Mac's. The game itself is pretty good. The two flaws that annoy me are: (1) Occasional omissions that make parts of the story incomprehensible (minor spoiler: Nico‚Äôs inferences about her father are unconvincing). Sometimes the story just ‚Äújumps‚Äù by putting information into the journal that the game did not actually provide in gameplay. (2) Some puzzles require completely ad-hoc solutions without any possibility of logical deduction. Trying out all possible combinations of inventory items with screen objects is simply boring. 4/5 stars.  The adaptation for Android is partially poorly done, however. Lack of touch sensitivity leads to many wrong clicks. Occasional bugs interrupt cut-scenes and thus hide important detail. Accidentally touching the display can interrupt descriptions/dialogs, and the information is lost forever, because not all descriptions can be shown repeatably. The sound quality is abhorrently poor. The visual art is okay, and some of the backgrounds look great, but the figures are of poor quality, compared to other games of the same era. And finally, the game saps an unjustifiable amount of battery because it‚Äôs clearly not optimised for mobile architecture. 2/5 stars.

I feel at a loss for words when trying to describe this game.. It is honestly one of the best games I have ever played on a mobile device, if not THE best. Worth every single penny and then some. The graphics are fantastic, the puzzles are so awesome, the story and characters are brilliant, everything about this game is remarkable. Truly incredible game, I couldn't recommend any further. Especially if you enjoy "point and click" type of games, which personally are my favourite, this outweighs the competition in my opinion. Also may be for fans of puzzle type games that are challenging but not too difficult (there are also tips you can access to aide you if you get stuck at any point). Just wonderfully executed game all around. I will absolutely be looking for all content from the developers, Bravo!

content: This is a great game. If you're a fan of action adventure (aka point and click adventure) games, this is a must. It's got a slightly more involved story than the classic Monkey Island games and the humour is subtler. The puzzles are nicely pitched whereby they're challenging without being too frustrating. In some cases I found I wasn't clear what I was meant to be doing but the puzzle hints kept me on track. All in all a great find.

replyContent: Hi Ian - sorry to hear about these problems. I would suggest deleting the SETTINGS.ELA file in your "bs1dc_saves" directory. If this does not work, please email us at Catherine@Revolution.co.uk and we'll try and fix this issue for you.

content: Brings back good memories

content: A great game. Occasional crashes are not hard to recover from, fortunately. The only major issue is that the bottom line of the notebook is cut off - I hope this will not be a problem.

Ive played many adventure games and this is by far my favorite!! The story keeps you wanting to play. The puzzles fit right in to the story line. Its difficult enough to  make you think but not enough to make you loose interest. If you happen to get stumped there are very helpful FREE hints that come in parts as to not give the answer right away so you can keep trying and go all the way to instructions.  The story if filled with mystery, conspiracy,  and murder. It also comes with a side of comic relief.  I highly recommend this game to people who are overwhelmed with the average adventure games full of dull stories and have 'hidden object' mini games as majority of puzzles. I cant wait to play the next one! KEEP THEM COMING!!!!!!! THANK YOU!!!!!!

This is a great introduction to adventure games and a strong motive for kids to improve their english language skills. The director's cut looks good, the atmosphere and sound effects are significantly improved, and there are lots of new scenes. The controls feel even more natural on a tablet than the original did on a PC with a mouse and keyboard. Keep in mind that it downloaded 0.5Gb of multimedia on my tablet (it might be less for mobile phones).  Responsive, no crashes so far on a 2011 tablet running Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich). A 5 star rating doesn't do this game justice.

Loving the game so far, enjoying seeing a new take on the familiar characters and story line. A warning though, to customers and developers alike. On my nexus 7 this game is unstable as hell. Any user not as smitten by nostalgia as I would have given up in disgust long ago. Not what I expect from a paid for game. So, stylistically, narratively, nostalgically this is great...technically I am far from impressed. But....my investigation must continue.....

Revolution responds promptly to bug reports too!

This port onto android is a testament to the dedication of the original revolution crew, to put so much effort into bringing the game upto date, adding extra parts and perfecting the controls for touch is brilliant. Not just trying to make a quick cash in on an old classic, this is obviously a labour of love.

I finished the game and immediately wished there was a sequel, which I eventually completed too. I have oceans of fond memories and loving nostalgia for George and Nico...so this and BS2 were natural purchases. Still amazing 14 years on. 5*!

It's like the old school point and click adventure games. While it has some decent humor and creative puzzles, in the end these games revolve around talking to everyone about everything and trying every item in every click point.  Some puzzles in the last third of the game are flat-out weird and inscrutable, like the old King's Quest games where, to cross a bridge, you give a pirate a coin and he gives you a parrot, which you give to a doctor, who gives you a magnifying glass, which you use to find a buried vial of troll repellent, which you use on the troll on the bridge.  Also, the parchment that you go back to several times had severe performance problems for me and easily became unresponsive.

Contacted authors. No fix yet. Will change rating if they come up with fix.    Edit: With some testing I found the problem. The program created a directory on my external SD card but then was unable to access that directory during game play. I removed the external card and re-installed the program and got back the ability to Save and Restore games. BUT! I had lost all progress in the game. Catherine at Revolution Software was VERY helpful and created restore point files for me so I didn't have to replay the first half of the game again. Thank you Catherine!!!  I've updated the rating from 1 to 5 stars  solely for the excellent customer service communications!

Classic PC games that have been here for so long. I own all the versions and pretty much played all the games in the Broken Sword series from PC to console and now revisiting them on my Android device. The first 2 BS games feel right at home on touch screens as the game controls are simplistic in nature and are mainly Point & Click so anyone can pick it up easily. The game is presented in colourful 2D canvasses instead of the 3D version that graced the consoles in the form of Broken Sword: The Sleeping Dragon. What truly makes this game worth playing is the witty dialogue delivered by the main characters especially our hero George Stobbart in pole position followed shortly by our not-so damsel in distress and the feisty Nico Collard. The next would be the game play filled with a rich story of back stabbing and double dealing infused with myths and sorcery of gods and men from bygone eras. Revolution Software remain one of the very few rare gems from the golden age of PC gaming as independent studios such as Westwood have already fallen foul to the big publishers. This is a MUST BUY and for a low price such as this, it is simply the bargain of the century.

This game reminds one of the old LucasArts games like Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island and Indiana Jones.  It's well written and funny and the puzzles are just hard enough to keep it interesting without frustrating you.  The voice work, while not exactly realistic, is silly and charming.  The audio is a bit echo-y but it's fine.  They obviously put a lot of work into the dialogue.  My only complaint - and this is a personal preference - is that the game is a little too easy and linear.  A lot of the puzzles are obvious or simple. The game has other characters give you hints.  It often won't let you leave a location before you've finished what you need to do there and it will close out locations after there is nothing left to do (I actually appreciate the latter as I have nowhere near the time for this as I did when I was a kid).  And there are no consequences to your actions (ie you can never mess up) and your choices never deviate the story in any way.  LucasArts games were generally clever enough to punish the user for mistakes without the user getting stuck or having to start again (as could happen with Sierra adventure games or other text adventures).

A fan of old point and click adventure (Monkey Island, Quest for Glory, etc.), I have been waiting for some solid Android ports of these types of games (aside from Scumm emulation). I will admit that I'd never heard of the Broken Sword series before, but it is a solid addition to the genre, with a compelling narrative and interesting puzzles. It is a 10 hour game, which is significantly more entertainment than the 1-2 hours most Android adventure/puzzle games bring. I was able to get it for 25 cents, but I'd certainly pay $4.  I'm hoping to see more games from the Broken Sword series, and hopefully their success will spur companies like LucasArts and Telltale games to bring more point and click to Android.

This is a very engaging game with a good story and clever puzzles to solve.  Just 2 niggling issues that give me pause.  1. As a French-speaker, I find some of the voice acting - generally well-done - to be lacking in its general execution.  It just occurs to me that if you're going to set a story in France you should try to be as accurate in the pronunciation as possible.  It's very, very strange for random people to be lounging around Paris with English names.  Moreover, it's pretty rude to just come up to someone in France and start speaking to them in English. In this game, not only is that normal, but there's a 50/50 chance that the interlocutor speaks unaccented American English.  2. It'd be great if they could take a look at the resolution of the game - there's no reason it couldn't work better on a tablet.

I can manage to read the dialogue (which is also spoken), but it's well-nigh impossible to read the journal entries and it would be nice if there was an option to magnify those. Some of the plot exposition and dialogue is a little bit clunky, which is why I'm only giving it 4 stars and not 5, but it is still a totally absorbing experience to play and well worth downloading.

Stays true enough to the original while telling the story from a completely different angle. Very clever the way they have used the character Nicole to show us the all the stuff that went on behind the scenes that we never saw the first time around. I purchased this app just for a bit of nostalgia and never intended for it to take so much of my time up. There are enough puzzles in this rebirth to delight old and new fans alike and while the difficulty of the newer ones is not quite on par with its predecessor, they still keep you entertained. I always thought the puzzles in Broken Sword where a little too hard sometimes anyway. The old puzzles are still there though so you will still have plenty to do. The animation and scenes are even more beautifully painted than I remember thanks to a little re-mastery of the original graphics. The added touches and attention to detail are once again faultless. Some of the added touches are sweet, like being able to listen to music in Nicole's apartment (who is the singer and what is the track?), it appears to have nothing to do with the story. At last a point and click adventure that is not completely linear. Good work, a Revolution.

This game was among the very best adventure games for PC, and can now take the title for Android. The game itself retains all of the humour, intelligence and intrigue of the original but with the added bonuses of genuinely cool extended gameplay and a perfectly smooth touchscreen interface. Buy it, play it, love it!

Beautiful art, fun story,  very enjoyable. I do have some gripes though. Game is very linear. Conversation system has some issues: you can get responses referring to things that haven't been said/heard yet,  and once that happens,  conversation choices that would lead to those things being said are no longer available.  The hot spot interface seems like a decent solution to avoid pixel hunting, but since there are few of them on any screen, the fun of exploring the world is reduced.   Still, a great game!

What can make or break an adventure game is its story. Not only is Broken Sword's story good, it wipes the floor with anything out there right now on Google Play. (The only games I can think of that come as close are The Lost City and The Secret of Grisly Manor, but even those games are too short compared to this one.) What makes this game so compelling are its cast of likable characters that (shocker!) actually talk, making you feel involved and wanting to keep going to find out how it all ends. (Since this is a translation of the PC version, I didn't expect anything different.) I hope Revolution has started a trend. (You listening, LucasArts? Android is a perfectly viable platform too.) For the love of all that's holy, if you like/love those old PC "point-and-click" adventure games, *buy* this one right away. You won't be disappointed.

When I discovered Broken Sword on Android I was over the moon, this game is sensational and I feel actually plays even better than on DS - if that is possible! I had a couple of glitches to start with, the game wouldn't play past the opening video but an update with fix was out the next day. It still would not play on my HTC Sensation so checking Revolution's excellent site, found I needed to access Settings/Developer options and disable 'Don't keep activities'. The game now works beautifully, excellent graphics and sounds and great interface. For all Broken Sword fans and those yet to discover the best point and click adventure series ever devised, ¬£2.99 for this app is an absolute no brainer. Cannot recommend highly enough. Buy immediately to encourage Revolution to release more games on Android!!

5$ for a mobile game might seem outrageous, but that's because this world is insane.  Broken Sword is more than worth it.  Adventure games were nearly dead to me, but I kept thinking that they would be the perfect game to play during subway transit.  This game is proving me right so far.  Fantastic artwork, clever story, solid if slightly faux-french voiceovers.  Perfect hint system you can rely on if things get too hard, or you're just too tired after a day's work to figure things out.  Buy it, play it, love it.
